run out.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to use all of something and not have any more left
run out.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: I’ve got money you can borrow if you run out.
They ran out of money and had to abandon the project.
run out.translation[0].definitions[1].de: if something is running out, there will soon be none left
run out.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: We must act now because time is running out.
His luck had run out  (=there was none left).
run out.translation[0].definitions[2].de: if an agreement, official document etc runs out, the period for which it is legal or has an effect ends
run out.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: My contract runs out in September.
run out.translation[0].definitions[3].de: to have no more energy or no longer be interested in what you are doing
run out.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: The team seemed to have run out of gas.
run out.translation[0].definitions[4].de: to force someone to leave a place, because they have done something wrong
run out.translation[0].definitions[5].de: to end a player’s innings in the game of cricket by hitting the stumps with the ball while they are running
run out.translation[1].definitions[0].de: to use all of something and not have any of it left
run out.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: What happens when we run out of oil?
run out.translation[1].definitions[1].de: if something runs out, there is then none of it left
run out.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: Regulators close a bank when its capital runs out.
run out.translation[1].definitions[2].de: if an agreement or other official document runs out, it reaches the end of a period of time when it is officially allowed to continue
run out.translation[1].definitions[2].ex: My contract runs out in September.
